content.html: Yes. I am not sure whether using Static could cause any confusion here. So I explicitly use ActorStatic. I can change it back if Static appears to be more correct.

content.raw: Note that the `<actor>` tag can also contain [links, joints and plugins](#!/osrf/sdformat/src/08ea83caa185e305fcc5d21b80e0b388cf9901b0/sdf/1.6/actor.sdf#lines-87), so we need to expose those through the API as well.
content.html: Note that the <actor> tag can also contain links, joints and plugins, so we need to expose those through the API as well.

content.html: Sure. Do we need to modify the sdf file as well?

content.html: If you check the link on the comment above, you can see that they're already in the actor.sdf file, using <include>

content.raw: I checked the other codes in `include/sdf` and in `src`. It seems that the `plugin` tag has not been parsed yet. There is not `plugin.cc` and `plugin.hh`. The `sdf` file that contains `<plugin>`, e.g., `sdf::sensor` and `sdf::model`, does not have the `plugin` or equivalent members.
content.html: I checked the other codes in include/sdf and in src. It seems that the plugin tag has not been parsed yet. There is not plugin.cc and plugin.hh. The sdf file that contains <plugin>, e.g., sdf::sensor and sdf::model, does not have the plugin or equivalent members.

content.raw: Oh yes, sorry for the misleading comment. It's ok to leave plugin out for now; we're getting it from `Element`.
content.html: Oh yes, sorry for the misleading comment. It's ok to leave plugin out for now; we're getting it from Element.

content.raw: I am not sure but I guess the `links` and `joints` in `Actor` are supposed to be embedded in the animation or skin file. The `links` and `joints` are to describe the actor skeleton like a robot, right? Should we parse them in the `Actor.cc` and `Actor.hh`? Or we can parse them in the `Animation` ?
content.html: I am not sure but I guess the links and joints in Actor are supposed to be embedded in the animation or skin file. The links and joints are to describe the actor skeleton like a robot, right? Should we parse them in the Actor.cc and Actor.hh? Or we can parse them in the Animation ?

content.raw:
On Gazebo classic, Actor is not just a class for animation. It's more like an extension to models, so it can also have links and joints. So they're not tied to the animation or skin, they're directly under the `<actor>`. See [this example](http://gazebosim.org/tutorials?tut=actor&cat=build_robot#Worldexplained). Whether this is useful is a valid question though. I actually suspect that actor joints are useless, because neither physics nor the animation may be acting on them. We could consider decoupling the scripting of model trajectories from skeleton animation. 

So feel free to leave links and joints out for now while we get skeleton animations to work. Once we have that working, we can revisit the idea of scripting link motions and see if they still fit well within actors. Sounds good?
content.html:
On Gazebo classic, Actor is not just a class for animation. It's more like an extension to models, so it can also have links and joints. So they're not tied to the animation or skin, they're directly under the <actor>. See this example. Whether this is useful is a valid question though. I actually suspect that actor joints are useless, because neither physics nor the animation may be acting on them. We could consider decoupling the scripting of model trajectories from skeleton animation.

So feel free to leave links and joints out for now while we get skeleton animations to work. Once we have that working, we can revisit the idea of scripting link motions and see if they still fit well within actors. Sounds good?

content.raw: Yes, it’s good for me. Thanks for pointing to the example
content.html: Yes, it’s good for me. Thanks for pointing to the example
